reasoning: 1. Circle of Competence: I don’t understand the inner workings of EV battery chemistry, software complexity or rapidly evolving automotive regulations well enough to have confidence. As I’ve said, ‘Risk comes from not knowing what you’re doing.’ This market sits firmly outside my wheelhouse. 2. Competitive Moat: While Tesla has brand cachet, automobiles are commodity products with low switching costs. Legacy carmakers are pouring billions into EVs, and price competition will intensify. I see no enduring pricing power moat like Coca-Cola’s formula or Apple’s ecosystem. 3. Management: Elon Musk is a visionary, but his unpredictable capital allocation—fundraising at sky-high valuations, reinvesting heavily in new factories—and governance style differ from the disciplined, shareholder-oriented management I seek. 4. Financial Health: Tesla’s earnings have been volatile and tied to production ramps and regulatory credits. It’s a capital-intensive business with cyclical demand, unlike the consistent cash flow of an insurance operation or See’s Candies. 5. Valuation: At current multiples, TSLA trades at nosebleed valuations with no reliable intrinsic value estimate and zero margin of safety. I’d rather buy a wonderful business at a fair price. 6. Long-Term Prospects & Red Flags: EV penetration will grow, but competition and pricing pressure will erode margins. Rapid technology change and regulatory risk add extra uncertainty. 7. Comparison to My Portfolio: I prefer simple, time-tested franchises—Coca-Cola, Apple, BNSF—that earn predictable returns over decades. Tesla fails my first test: I don’t understand it well enough, and it lacks the durability and valuation cushion I demand. Therefore, I’m bearish on TSLA.
